attributes.title: Stock verification
attributes.description:
·       A physical stock count of raw materials and finished product was done on 27 February 2025, to determine whether the physical count of raw materials and finished product matches with the records as per SAP system and to assess the effectiveness of controls over inventory management.

·       The exercise showed that:

Ø  Bread Stock had a variance of -47.25 pieces

Ø  Polybags had +101 pieces

Ø  Brown flour had -2.95kgs

Ø  Wheat bran had -1.59kgs

Ø  White ingredient, brown ingredient, yeast and utto had immaterial variances as seen below:

·       Below is the summary of the audit findings:

Table 1:Stock Verification summary.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should enhance their stock controls to minimize / eliminate the identified variances.
attributes.effect: The variances noted are an indication that stock management controls are weak and there is a need to strengthen controls.

value: Stock controls are okey. We have put more controls by conducting shift wise stock takes to ensure there are minimal variations, we are working of further improvement.
Stock controls are okey. We have put more controls by conducting shift wise stock takes to ensure there are minimal variations, we are working of further improvement.

·       In the prior audit report dated 23rd January 2025 stock was as seen below:

ü  Polybags +238 pieces

ü  Finished product -250 pieces loaves after adjusting 60 pieces oven damage.

ü  White ingredient had -1.078 pieces.
Current

attributes.title: Crates verification
attributes.description:
·       A review of the branch crates balances was done to establish whether the controls for crates movement were sufficient.

·       It was noted that the branch crates agreed with those recorded in the system, however the branch had opening balances crates of 52 as seen below:

Table 2:Crates Movement.
attributes.recommendation: The branch Management to maintain the controls.
attributes.effect: The crates movement was well controlled.

value: Opening balance crates are those in the supermarkets but sales rep usually follows up by doing random spot checks.
Opening balance crates are those in the supermarkets but sales rep usually follows up by doing random spot checks.

In the prior audit report, it was noted that crates had nil variations as per the physical balances and managers records, however a variance of -157 pieces were noted as per system and physical balances
Current

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       A cash verification was conducted at the cashier’s office on 27 February 2025, to ensure that the cash balances matched the cash flow records and that the established cash handling standards were being followed.

·       A variance of KES -331,920 was noted in the physical cash available, which was attributed to an unresolved fraud case from previous years that had been escalated to the security, legal, and accounts teams. While there was an excess of KES 7, resulting in a variance of KES -331,913 in the cash count, the missing amount according to the records was KES 331,920.

·       It was also observed that there were 3 pending IOUs worth KES 11,500 out of which one for KES 2000 was past the 3-day clearance policy. This was as detailed below:

Table 3:Cash verification summary.
attributes.recommendation: ·     The branch management is recommended to reclassify the noted amount to other receivables or legal claim receivable if legal action has been taken or provide for the same under provision for doubtful debts if recovery is uncertain to avoid misstatement of cash balances.
attributes.effect: The lost funds identified during the cash count indicate weaknesses in internal controls for cash management.

value: Accounts to deal with the long outstanding cash out.
Accounts to deal with the long outstanding cash out.

·       In the prior audit report dated 23rd January 2025, it was noted that there was a variance of KES -331,920 in physical cash available which was attributed to unsettled case of fraud from previous year which had been escalated to security/legal/accounts team. There was an excess of KES 5 leading to a variance of KES -331,915 in our cash count, but the missing amount was KES 331,920 as per records
Current

attributes.title: Bread weights
attributes.description:
·       A random weight check for packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market was done to determine if they were of standard weight of 200g, 400 g,600g,800g and 1.5 kgs as per the KEBS requirements.

·       Underweights were noted across all varieties as seen:

Ø  400 CTW/BT was 37% underweight and 20% overweight, Average overall weight was 397.57.

Ø  600 BT/CTW had 30.7% underweight, and 2.7% overweight average weight was 590.33

Ø  800 CTW had 57% underweight and 4% overweight average weight was 779.01

Ø  White Bread 400 Barrel 57% underweight and 9 % overweight average weight was 386.63.

·       Below is the detailed summary of the findings:

Table 4:Bread weight Check.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management is recommended to ensure correct production procedures be followed to avoid lapses that cause underweight bread.
attributes.effect: The presence of underweight and overweight bread indicates lapses in follow-up of correct production procedures from mixing to packing.

value: Bread weights were caused by overbaking and laxity in follow up of correct production process especially from baking to packing, more supervision will be enhanced to ensure correct procedures are followed to avoid lapses that cause underweights bread.

·       There is a need for proper supervision from Mixing to packing to ensure SOPs are strictly followed and if there is laxity there is some employees’ action be taken.

More Frequent spot checks to be also done on both dough and packed bread to minimize cases underweights bread.

·       In the previous audit report dating 23rd January 2025, underweights were noted as illustrated below:

ü  400 CTW had 12%

ü  600 CTW/BT had 72%

ü  800 CTW 62%

ü  800 Barrel 3%

ü  6 Barrel 13%

ü  1.5 CTW/BT 0%
Current

attributes.title: Bread damages.
attributes.description:
·       An analysis was done on the bread damage levels for both production and market-based deformities for the period 34 days from 24 January 2025 to 26 February 2025 was done to determine if they were within the allowable threshold of 0.2% and 0.5% respectively.

·       It was noted that:

ü  Production damages stood at 0. 0.30% of total production which was above the set limit of 0.2%

ü  Market damages stood at 0.51% of total sales, which was above the set limit of 0.5% as demonstrated in the table below:

Table 5:Production Damages.

NB: The production damages analysis above excludes 155 loaves for oven damages and 91 loaves for deduction damages.

Table 6:Market Damages.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should enhance controls within the production process to ensure bread produced is of good quality thereby minimizing the possibility of excess production and market damages.
attributes.effect: Production damages exceeded the allowable limit by 0.1 % leading to an extra cost incurred of KES 31,527.48 While Market damage exceeded the allowable limit by 0.01% leading to extra cost incurred of KES 3,199.4 and therefore implied compromised bread quality and poor control of balances for the audited period.

value: ·   Excess production damages were caused by overbaked bread due to laxity of production workers. We will strengthen supervision to ensure correct baking time is followed to minimize excess PD.Excess market damages were caused by bread mishandling and deformed bread, we will implement additional controls, particularly over the sales team, to prevent mishandling of bread thus minimizing market damages.

·    Excess production damages were caused by overbaked bread due to laxity of production workers. We will strengthen supervision to ensure correct baking time is followed to minimize excess PD.Excess market damages were caused by bread mishandling and deformed bread, we will implement additional controls, particularly over the sales team, to prevent mishandling of bread thus minimizing market damages.

·       During the prior audit it was noted that production damages were 0.312% of the total production while market damages were 0.68% of the total sales.Damages sent to ingredient had - 40.55kgs which was equivalent to 101.375 Loaves worth KES 5,372.88.
Current

attributes.title: Production efficiency
attributes.description:
·       A review of the branch’s utilization of human capital resources allocated to the production section for a period of 34 days from 24 January to 26 February 2025 was conducted to determine if production workers were achieving their set production targets of 4.3 bags per worker

·       It noted that the production efficiency was at 4.21 bags which was below the standard of 4.3 bags ,15 extra workers were hired with a cost implication of KES 16,299 as detailed in the summary below:

Table 7:Production efficiency
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure proper allocation of workers is done as per the shift targets and ensure they are optimally utilized.
attributes.effect: Production workers did not achieve their set KPI of 4.3 bags, this implied that extra cost of KES 16,299 was incurred for over-allocation of 15 extra production workers.

value: Production efficiency is sometimes affected by oven breakdowns, but we will put more controls to ensure efficiencies are achieved.
For Production efficiency we will try to ensure proper allocation is done at the start of the shift and enhance supervision of production workers to ensure they achieve their set KPI.
The previous audit report dated 23rd January 2025 indicated a production efficiency of 4.12 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing efficiency
attributes.description:
·       An evaluation was performed on the performance of packers in the slicing section to verify whether they were meeting the company’s established target of 97 crates per packer.

·       It was noted that, for the period of 34 days from 24 January 2025-26 February 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 84.92 crates per packer which was below the standard set, extra 56 workers were hired with a cost implication of KES 51,072.

Table 8: Packing Efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure slicers are allocated as per the prior shift loaves produced and tighten supervision to ensure slicing efficiency is achieved.
attributes.effect: Packers did not achieve their set efficiency of 97 crates per slicer, this implied that an extra 56 workers were hired with a cost implication of KES 51,072.

value: We will push packers to ensure they are achieving their set efficiency.
We will push packers to ensure they are achieving their set efficiency.
The previous audit report dated 23rd January 2025 indicated a packing efficiency of 92.13 crates per packer.
Current

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of both the mixing chart and mixing chart summaries for the period of 34 days from 24 January 2025-26 February 2025 was conducted to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.

·       The analysis showed that:

Ø  Average yield was 191.52 loaves per bag

Ø  Average production was 81.57 bags equivalent to 81.57% of the set target of 112 bags.

Ø  Utto units’ consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1

Ø   396 cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:

Table 9:Mixing Chart analysis.
attributes.recommendation:
·       The branch management to improve on yield and production target achievement.

·       Correct Production procedures to be followed to avoid overproof which lead to remixes.
attributes.effect: ·       Branch production capacity was not optimally utilized by 18.43%.Remixes noted implies there was a lapse in following of correct production process and bread quality was affected.

value: ·       Production target achievement sometimes is affected by Oven breakdowns, but we are working on improvement.Remixes were caused by Overproof, but we will ensure correct production procedures are followed to avoid cases of remixes.

·       Production target achievement sometimes is affected by Oven breakdowns, but we are working on improvement.Remixes were caused by Overproof, but we will ensure correct production procedures are followed to avoid cases of remixes.

·       During the prior audit, mixing chart analysis showed:

Utto units’ consumption to bags was 1:1

ü  Average yield 191.64 loaves per bag.

ü  Average production was at 88.78 bags equivalent to 82.21% of the target of 108 bags.

656 Remixes were noted.
Current

attributes.title: Minishop spot check
attributes.description:
·       A spot check on Mini shop was done on 27February 2025 to determine if all loaded bread was accounted for and if the sales were equivalent to the till balances given that the mini shop did not accept physical cash.

·       It was noted that all the sales done at the time of the spot check were accounted for and all the expected bread balances from loading made exclusive of sales were physically available, however there was a positive variance of KES 3,217 between expected cash and cash as per mpesa till which was due to a customer who had paid and had not been supplied with bread detailed below:

Table 10:Mini-shop spot Check.
attributes.recommendation: The management should maintain the Mini shop controls and keep track of transaction charges.
attributes.effect: All sales were all accounted for, Mini shop controls are working effectively

value: Sales team to discourage advance payments, customers to pay upon receipt of bread.
Sales team to discourage advance payments, customers to pay upon receipt of bread.
In a prior audit report dated 23rd January 2025, Mini shop spot check had nil variations.
Current

attributes.title: Vehicles Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
·       A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 1 February to 27 February 2025.

·       It was noted that all route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard as detailed in Appendix I below:
attributes.recommendation: Maintain and enhance the fuel management controls within the branch.
attributes.effect: All route vehicles’ fuel consumption was well controlled.

value: Excess fuel consumed is due to Faulty mileage readings and one car which broke down and was allocated fuel, KAF to speed up repairs to minimize these issues.
Excess fuel consumed are due to Faulty mileage reading and one car which broke down and was allocated fuel, KAF to speed up repairs to minimize this issues.
During the previous audit dated 23rd January 2025, vehicles fuel consumption was within the set standards.
Current

attributes.title: Debtors analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balances as of 28 February 2025 was done to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       It was noted that there was an outstanding balance of KES 254,371.7 and two dormant accounts totaling to KES 16,395.8

·       The summary of the debtors’ balances is detailed below in Table 11 Appendix 1:
attributes.recommendation: ·       Follow up on pending balances for clearance.
attributes.effect: Debt balances were minimal; however, sales rep should follow up on the two dormant accounts for the outstanding balances to be recovered from security deposits.

value: We control balances and supply by checking customer security deposits, if it is above the debt and order we supply, to minimize the risk of non-payment.
We control balances and supply by checking customer security deposits, if it is above the debt and order we supply, to minimize the risk of non-payment.
In the Prior audit report debtors’ balances were at 80,445, which were under sales rep follow up however the customers debts were below their security deposits
Current

attributes.title: Generator fuel consumption
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of generator fuel consumption was done for a period of 28 days from 1 February to 28 February 2025 to check if consumption were as per standard rates

·       It was noted that fuel consumption was at 25.22 l/h which was within the range.
attributes.recommendation: Generator fuel consumption controls to be maintained.
attributes.effect: ·       Generator fuel consumption was within range.

value: Generator fuel controls to be maintained
Generator fuel controls to be maintained
N/A
Current

attributes.title: Supermarket Returns
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of supermarket returns for a period of 34 days from 24th January 2025-26th January 2025 was done to determine the reasons for returns and the magnitude of the returns.

·       A total of supermarket returns of 1378.5 pieces 400 conversion were noted, out of which 748.5 were due to expiry and 612 were due to quality issues Naivas supermarket was noted to have significant returns due to expiry.

·       Below is a detailed bar graph of the returns:
attributes.recommendation: ·       Bread rotation controls in supermarkets should be enhanced to reduce instances of bread expiry and ensure that no excess orders are placed.For quality issues the branch should ensure proper production procedures are followed to ensure bread of desired quality is sent to the market
attributes.effect:
·       Excess supermarket returns due to expiry issues indicate that there is poor rotation of bread in supermarkets.

·       Returns due to quality is an indication that the branch is not following correct production procedures which compromise the bread quality.

value: ·     Expiry cases are caused by supermarkets stock control and proper handling of the products to be enhanced..Quality cases were due to overbaked and underbaked, we will ensure correct production procedures are followed to ensure the bread produced is of good quality to minimize returns due to product quality.

Expiry cases are caused by supermarkets stock control and proper handling of the products to be enhanced..Quality cases were due to overbaked and underbaked, we will ensure correct production procedures are followed to ensure the bread produced is of good quality to minimize returns due to product quality.
N/A
Current

attributes.title: 14.	Data inconsistencies between Market Damages as per SAP and manager’s book.
attributes.description:
·       A comparison of damages for 34 days from 24 January 2025 to 26 February 2025 was done to check if damages as per managers book and SAP were accurately recorded.

·       It was noted that the system had excess market damages as compared to the manager’s book which was due to failure to record supermarket returns in the manager’s damages book as detailed below.

Table 11: Market damages (Mgrs. book vs SAP).
attributes.recommendation: Proper recording of supermarket credit notes should be done to avoid discrepancies between managers’ book and SAP.
attributes.effect: Failure to record all the damages will lead to variations between damages sent to ingredient and those that are Actually available.

value: Credit notes will be accounted for going forward in the manager’s book to minimize the variations.
Credit notes will be accounted for going forward in the manager’s book to minimize the variations.
N/A
Current
